div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,576] ALEXANDRIA, Monday, August 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 11.30 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The Case for Greece
div.p: In view of the excitement in Athens over the suggested reforms in Crete, the critical situation in Macedonia, and the German official protest against any aeparate settlement of the Cretan question likely to disturb the status (/uo, the case fur the Greeks deserves tu be understood, fur of late the Græco- Bulgarian eonflict in Macedunia his produced net a few critics who seem te consider that the Greek nation is in this case the provoker. We will take the Cretan question fir$t, as that has reached a délicate position and is more closely associated with Hellenic ainis. The four protecting Powers, Great Britain, Russia, France, and Italy, a few weeks ago, under pressure of the constant and unaninious Cretan demand for annexation to Greece, and under the threat of Prince George of Greece, the High Commissioner, to resign, formulated a reform scheme professedly put forward to satisfy, as far as possible, the aspi-rations of the Cretan peuple. This project of reform, as a whole, lias created immense disappointinent, or even indignation, through¬out Greece and Crete, and the Powers hâve now intimatxl te the Greek Government that they are considering a modification of the scheme. Briefiy, the reforrns provide for :

(1) the creation of a Militia, the withdrawal of the Italian officers from the Gendarmerie, and the appointment of Greek Army officers to conimand the whole, provided these officers aie struck oft the active list of the Greek Army} (2) a qualified promise of the évacuation of the island by the foreign troops at a time not specified ; (3) the extension of the financial Control Commission at Athens to einbraco Cretan finance ; and (4) the right of the Consuls of the protecting Powers to supervise the acts of the High Commissioner’s Ministirs or Councillors. And ail this in the interests of order in Crete and of the protection of the Moslem minority. There are other minor points.

The Greek objections te these reforms may be stated thus : In the first place the world aeknowledges Greece’s pre-eminent ethno- graphieal, geographical, and historical daims in Crete. The appointment of a Greek Prince as High Commissioner after the Græco- Turkish War proves that. Again, the entire Cretan population is Hellenic. Out of 301,000 some 33,000 are Mohamedans, but even these are Greok and speak only Greek. Then, again, Crete has proved that there is no Christian versus Moslem question under fr(>. j institutions—in fact sinee the appointment of Prince George absolute tranquillity would bave resulted had it not been for the intrigues of certain interested Power». And the Cretam bave been quiet, and Greece has loyally urgod peaceful acquiescence in the régime of the last eight years, firrnly believing that union with Greece would be the reward of such an attit ude. There is no more Moslem trouble in Crete than there is in Thessaly. Prince George would not countenance it. King Georgo again, is one of the most enlightened of Eur./ pean rulers, and most liberal and kindly ininded, and ail his efforts hâve been and will lie towards complété harmony in thô island. Take Thessaly. So amicably do the Greeks live with Mohamedans there that Thessaly actually serïds deputies of the Moslem faith to theAthenian Chamber. It is in this spirit that Moslems bave been appointed to various offices in Crète by the présent High Commis sioner. Thus if there is every évidence (,f assured tranquillity and harmony, provided that foreign intriguera cease to hâve the pré¬sent reason for meddling in Cretan aftairs, why do the Powers delay to grant union with the raotherland f Why do they pré¬sent reforrns which are calculated to wound both Greek and Cretan amour propre, and te defer annexation indefinitely, and which will if put into force fling the whole Cretan question back into the misérable posi-. tion from which it has emerged I The fact is the British Government would grant annexa¬tion, but cannot accord it alone. Italy is not too friendly te Greece, having aspirations in Epirus, Albania, etc. France is compelled te please Russia now as much as ever. Russia will always oppose Greek airas. And now Germany, who withdrew from the Cretan complication years ago, official ly pronounces against the proposed reforrns, not from a Greek point of view, but because she déclarés them calculated to hasten annexation wishes the statua guo to be maintained.

Of course neither Greece nor Crete can oppose the will of the Powers. If the Powers cannot grant annexation now they at least hâve no reasons for rendering it more difficult in the near future. Greek sentiment would be satisfied if the Greek officers be not compelled to quit the Greek Army, that being considérai an unjust demand, debarring them from their legitimate military ambitions in the Mother Country; it would be satisfied if Crotan finance be left to Cretans—the International control of the Greek finances is humiliating to a proud people ; it would be satisfied if the foreign Consuls, as in any other country, be confined to making any représentations their Govern- ments may consider necessary to the High Commissioner—whereas the new proposai cannot but undermine his authority. In a word, union is the only fair thing for both parties. If union be deferred indefinitely, or if the suggested reforrns be carried through, the Cretan trouble will recommence. But let us say it has no possible connection with the the Macedonian question, as the German Press now prétends.

As regards Macedonia the facts are as follow: There was no Macedonian trouble until four years ago. Macedonia is largely Hellenised, but it has for some décades been subject te a Bulgarian propaganda, the Bulgarians being determined to oust the Greek element in readi- ness for possible eventualities. Four years ago the Bulgarian propaganda assumed the fonn of force—until then it had been social, educa- tional, political, or religious, as you like. Armed bands were formed under the eyes of the Bulgarian Go.vernment in Sofia and in other Bulgarian towns,and despatched to Mace¬donia to persécute the Greeks and Bulgarise unprotectod villages. Within a year or two over one thousand Greeks, men, women, and chil- dren, were brutallÿ doue to death by these Komitadjis. The Greek Govérnment protestod time after time to Turkey and to the Greek Powers. Nothing, or next to nothing, has been done to stay the Bulgarian atrocities. British Blue-books give a long list of the mas¬sacres, village by village. Hitherto the Greek Government endeavoured to assist the Powers, policed the Græco-Turkish frontier, and ordered the Greek Consuls to prevent the local forma¬tion of Greek armed bands. But short of a Chinese wall or the total prohibition of ail peaceful transit between Greece and Macédonian Army that even gréater military Powers tlian Greece could provide could wholly prevent the passage of adventurous patriots resol ved to avenge their kith and kin.

The Greeks Smart under the loss of cKlldren, brothers, womenkind, schools, and churches. It.is only recently that they hâve commeuced to retaliate. And now, when the Bulgarian» hâve begun to disCover that Macedonia is not Bulgarian, they hâve commenced to murder Greeks in Bulgaria itself. Last year it was Rumania, now it is Bulgaria. Everything points to coneerted action between the two States. Ail these recent barbarous act», notably in Philipj>opolis, Tatar-Bazardjik, Peristera, Stenimaka, Burgas, and Anchia- los, show the race hatred for Greece owing to her prépondérance in Macedonia. This is the Hellenic view held in Athens to-day. It is not a religious question, although the Greek Patriarch regards the Bulgarian Orthodox as schismatics It is a race question, Slavs versu» llellenes. Who is responsible The Great "owers undoubtedly. And how will it end i Unfortunately armed intervention would ap- pjar to be the only ptoper remedy.

div.head: Local AND GENERAL
div.p: Cairo Dancing Saloons.
The new moral oode formulated by the Goavernorat of Cairoapplies equally to dancing saloons.
Helouan Railway.
The doubled line of the Helouan Railway between Cairo and Tourah is shortly to ba open for traffic.
Omnibuses for Aktimln.
The application of Mr Taodoros, a Sohag merchant, for a fifteen years' concession of an omnibus service at Akhmin has been aocepted. Post Offioe for Cabbari.
A post office for all the branches ol the postal service—groups, specie paokets except¬ed—will be opened at Gabbari on 1st Septem¬ber next.
indeoent Assault
A Syrian bum-boatman of about 30 years at Suez has been apprehended on the oharge of committing an indecent assault on a little Italian girl of six.
“Undesirables."
The expulsion of European “undesirables” continues. Tw > were shipped by the Khedivial mail-boat yesterday, and Two otherp, who had been previously expelled,left for Greece. Vagranoy Law.
The maximum penalty for vagranoy, accord¬ing to the new draft law, is six instead of twelve months. The draft will be submitted to the Legislative Council at to day’s sitting.
Nungovioh Hotels Co.
A Cairo contempoiary states that the George Nungovioh Hotels Company has pur¬chased the land ccoupied by the King’s stables in Atheis in order to erect a magnificent hotfl on the site.
Burled Alive.

Iu the D^rb El-Mahrous quarter of Cairo, on Tuesday night, one of the walls of the housi of Sheikh Mohamed E Refai collapsed, burying in its ruins the sheikh’s little daughter. Life wai extinct by ths time the body was extricated.
Fatality at Ibrahimieh.

At 9 o’clock last night a Syrian female ser¬vant, aged 20, named Hellena Khalil, was run over by a tramcsr near Ibrahimieh and had her feet cot off. The unfortunate girl was taken to the G.eik Hospital, where she suooumbed to her injuries this morning.
Roman Sarcophagus Found.

A sarcophagus of white stone, reotangular inform, and said to belong to the Roman epoch, hap, says the “Mier,” been found at Karmout. in the district of Samanoud, by Mohamed Effendi Chabaan, inspector of anti¬quities of the provinces of Sharkieh and Dakahlieh.
Attempted Murder.

A dastardly attempt at murder was com¬mitted in Cairo on Taesday evening by an Italian named Leoni, a collector by profession, living in the rue Gomaa Sharkae, who slashed at an Arab man servant with a rszir, ii flicting gashes in the left arm which will require a fortnight’s hospital.
Mew Beoondary 8ohool.

On Tuesday last, Lord Edward Cecil, Dr. Dunlop, and Mr. Webb inspected the site selected by the Government for the new secondary school building at Alexandria, and after deliberation the officials decided to ask the Ministry of Finance to open a credit of about L.E. 15%000 for the purchase of the ground.
Mr. Plunkett's Case.

Mr. Plunkett, the proprietor of Au De Rouge, brought an action in the Cairo Italian Consular Court against two Jews whom he aooased of violation of dtmioile and destruc¬tion of merchandise. The Court waived the first count bat held the defendants gailty of injuring the plaintiff’s goods and ordered them to pay a fine of 100 frs. apiece and costs. Italian Consular Court

The Correctional Tribunal of the Italian Consulate in Cairo yesterday heard the oase of Nungcvioh 0, Fiado. The latter is charged with having, in Jane last, purloined jewellery be longing to M. Alexander Nungovich. The accased is 30 years of age and has already been imprisoned for various thefts. Judgment was postponed in order to hear the proseootor and his witnesses, who are at present absent from Cairo.
“The Rising Mile.”

The military band performance which was held on Tuesday night in the Esbekieh Gardens was made notable by a new and welcome featore — a march entitled “ The Rising Nile, ” oomposed by Lient Col. J.D.F. Doncgan, whose soDgs are known to many of us. The march is a most lively and harmonious composition and is written in excellent march¬ing time. The band of the 2nd Royal Innis- killing Fusiliers did fall justice to it, and their perfowuanoe and its own merits gained a well deserved enoore. We hope to hear it again, not once bat often, and that it will not be the last of Lieat.-Col. Donegan’s composi¬tions with which we shall be favoured, new Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap¬plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: MET THE KING AT COWES.
The amouncemeut of the Khedive’s visit to Cowas is confirmed. His Highness had a con-versation of fifteen minutes’ duration with the King.
The Khedive is expected to arrive at Con-stantinople between the Htli and 10th Scptem her. He will stay there until the beginning of October.
Shawki Bey, translator to the Khedive, left Alexandria yesterday by the Khedivial Line steamer for Constantinop’e, in obedience to the summons of the Khedive.

div.head: THE LATE CHERIF PASHA.
div.p: FUNERAL IN CAIRO.

The body of the late Mohamed Pasha Cherif arrived at Cairo by speoial train from Alexan¬dria at a quarter to eleven on Tuesday night and was oonveyed direotly to the deoeased’s palace in 8haria el Dawawin, accompanied only by his relations and a few intimate friends. Yesterday afternoon the friends and acquain¬tances of the late Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs were received at the palace previous to the funeral ceremonies.

Large crowds had collected in the streets to witness the passing of the sad procession and within the courtyard and the hall of the palace the servants and numerous friends had assem¬bled preparatory to accompanying the defanot to his final resting place. Among these were all who had served with him in hi3 public life who are at present in Cairo, and representatives of all the Consulates, public offiies, and many private friends.

The funeral convoy left the palaoe at a quarter to five and proceeded direct to Imam el Sefai, where the body was laid to rest. The respect in which the deoeased was held was made evident not only by the large numbers who accompanied the prooession, but by the crowds which lined the route, to the cemetery and paid their last silent homage to a once* popular public servant.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The regular meeting of the Alexandria Mnrioipal Delegation should have been held, as naaal, on Tuesday, but owing to the fane- rals of Mohamed Pasha Cherif and Mr. Xeno¬phon Constantinidis it was put off until yeste d »y. However, owing to two members not being able to be present, the meeting has again put eff until Saturday.

At the present time the Mnnioipal Council¬lors who are absent in Europe include Maltre Padoa Bpy, M. Escoffisr, Baron Alfred de Menasce,Dr. Valentin, Mr. Benachi, Mr. Emma¬nuel Stross, Mr. Salvago, and Mr. Foster,while the only Europeans remaining are Messrs. Ralli, Zervudachi, Batbiza, Rieti, and Tamba- copoulo.

A correspondent writes suggesting that gen-tlemen who have the honour to be elected mem¬bers of the Municipality should forego their annnal v»pit to Europe so as to prevent the affairs of the city remaining at a standstill. He also suggests that during epidemics saoh as cholera the members of the Mnnioipality should aotually be prohibited from leaving the country.

div.head: TURKISH TRANSPORTS.
div.p: The passage of the Turkish troopships for the Yemen has created created quite a stir at Port Said, and owing to the fear of mutiny, precautions were taken by the locU Governor against suoh an eventuality, polioemcn and ooast guards being told off to watch the vessels.

There were fifteen oases of typhoid fever amoDgst the soldiers on the Bezmir Alem, which and the Tir Moazhan entered the Canal at 3 p.m. yesterday utder close police escort. Five tf these fifteen patients, who were landed, have died.
As a precautionary measure the transport was disinfeoted before being allowed into the Canal. The third transport, the Abdul Kadir, enters the canal to-day.

Mariners are again cautioned not to pass between the breakwater end and the pivot gas baoy, as tin water is rapidly shoaling, on aooount of the large amouut of spoil which has been deposited between these points.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: In referenoe to the confidential cironlar which has been addressed by the Egyptian Government to the board of direotors of the National Bank of Egypt, we understand that the Government is willing that the bank should use a certain proportion of its own oapital and reserve fund for the style of basiness in which it is at present engaged, and in consideration for the work done by the bank on behalf of the Government in the interior, a certain sum would be left by the Govern-ment free of interest* at the bank’s disposal.

div.head: THE OLYMPIA CASE.
div.p: Re the action brought by M. Galenzi against Ismalum Bey for breach of contraot, the Court of Referees has sent the matter before the Mixed Tribunal, counsel for the defendant having praotically admitted snob breach.

According to the contraot, Ismalum Bey had undertaken to build on the property of Prince Djelal, arid deliver by Jaly to M. Galenzq a theatre to be known as the O'ympia, for which plaintiff had brought out a variety troupe. The building was not finished by the date stipulated, nor is it yet; and in the meantime M. Galenzi has had to hire other premise? for his oompany. He is represented, subjudice, by Me. Goarnotta.

div.head: Egyptian Army
div.p: Leave of absence has been granted to the following officers of the Egyptian Army:— Kaimakim Barges Bey, senior inspec¬tor of tin Berber provinoe, until October 39 ; El Kaimakam Young Bey, sub-governor of the Khartoum provinoe, until October 30 j BI Kaimakam Kennedy Bey, D.S.O., director of works, until October 2D ; El Bimbashi Par¬sons, janior inspeotor of the Berber province, until November 1 ; and El Bimbashi Airy, janior inspeotor of the Bahr el Ghazal province, antil November 19. A fortnight’s extension of leave has been granted to El Kaimakam Morant Bey, Governor of Haifa provinoe, who will accordingly resume his duties on Octo¬ ber 15.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA NATIVE COURT.
div.p: The Native Court of Alexandria yesterday sentenced two native vagabonds of Rahmanieh, Behera, to 10 years’ penal servitude for the mnrder of another vagabond of that village; and sentenced a Bedouin of Kom-el-Hassil, Itai el-Barond Markaz, to 7 years’ penal servitude for firing at a Sudanese with intent to kill. Two natives of Damanhoar Markaz, who were sospeoted of murdering a Be diain of Dessoanis, were acquitted by the same Coart yesterday as no evidence was forthcoming to prove the aoenseds’ guilt.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.

The Me9sager:e3 Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrned at Marseilles yesterday morning from Alexandria.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT. EXTENSION OF SPHERE OF OPERATIONS.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Ltd., was held last Thursday at Winchester House, Old Broad-street, E.C.,Sir Auckland Colvin,K.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E. (the Chairman of the com¬pany), presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. F.J. Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting and the auditor’s report,

The Chairman said: The report and acoonnts before ns, which 1 presume yon will take as read, are for half a year only, for which I pre¬pared yon at our general meeting in December last, and though I shall be happy to explain them so far as I am able, I wish to pass from them to a more general description of our posi¬tion, in which I must review the whole period oMbejompany’s existenoe. I shall not detain you by again going over the ground covered by our recent extraordinary meeting, when you sanctioned the re3plntions, which will be pat to yon for confirmation immediately after the close of this mee'ing.bnt I have still to ask yon to realise that the whole status of our company has been materially changed from that on which it was started in 1904, with a comparatively small oapital of £ICO,OOO under the auspices of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways. Under our original oonditions we effected some very good purchases,and were enoonraged to increase our oapital, but I pointed out to yon at our last general meeting th-vt the prices of land in our particular sphere of operations had risen so rapidly that we hesitated to boy further. We have since that time been ab'e to acquire other properties, notably the valuable properties of Les Moulins Francis d’Egypte, but in some oases we have had to depart from the letter of oar original intentions, so far as our memo¬randum and artioles of association permitted, and yon can readily understand the serious dis¬advantage under which we laboured in having to face keen competition in our own limited sphere of operations,without being able to enter into basiness outside of it. I am pleased to be able to state that although we thus suffered in what I will deseribe as a restricted quantity of basiness, we made up for it in quality, and I take this opportunity of mentioning that great credit is due to Captain A. Adams, R.E , for the selections of land purchased by him in his daal oapaoity of agent and general manager of the railways, and of manager of thii oompany in Egypt. We can hardly hope to repeat such bargains, and though time is neoessarily taken up in developing or disposing of these proper¬ties, so as to bring profits to aooount, we oan claim that such profits have been found to have continuously grown in amount Satisfactory Land SaJes.

Following the preparations which I told y. u we were mak'ng, we have held a sale of plots of land for building purposes on an estate of about 1,809,000 square metres, ray 430 feddans or acres, which we own in the proximity of Cairo, and thoagh the results do not appear in the accounts before yon, the sales having been held at and after the olose of the period, they proved highly satisfactory and continuously improving. Other profitable sales have also been effected, but do not for tho same reason appear in these acoonnts. I rhall have to refer to them later, but mention them here in Bnpport of what I have said. The time has now arrived when it is very necessary for ns to extend our sphere of operations in order to avail ourselves more generally of the oppor¬tunities which offer in Egypt and the Sudan. The arrangement of this involved the severance of our oonneotion with the Delta Light Rail¬way Company—te the regret of bolh com¬panies I may say—whose memorandum of association did not permit of their reserve funds even being invested in a land oompany whose business is thus unrestrioted. Subj°ot to the consent of the Court, we became an independent Land and Investment Company by yonr to-day confirming the resolutions to this end. We shall oontinue to extend to the railway company its right to purchase lands from us to meet its own requirements on speoial terms, and mast give dae consideration to any representation they may make to ns in conse¬quence of the severanoe of the oonneotion be¬tween the two companies. In the early part of this year we availed ourselves of the presence in Egypt of one of our London direotors to carefolly consider our fntnre methods of busi¬ness. Valuable properties were then purchased. Oar Board in Egypt was strengthened by the nomination of Mr. J. W. Williamson, of Cairo, thereto, and we shall proceed to appoint one or two direotors, as soon as we deoide upon the most suitable gentlemen, as further additions to that section of the Board. Iu some matters we are necessarily and greatly dependent upon the recommendations of the Board in Egypt, and we wish to feel that such are based upon wide consideration.
The Question of the Staff,

The question of our staff was also gone into on the spot. I had prepared yon for additional appointments being made thereto, but the more expended consideration of this matter was forced upon ns by the threatened reoall of Captain Adams to India, and now by our sepa¬ration from the railway oompany. Captain Adams’s services were fioally aud wholly trans¬ferred to the Egyptian Delta Light Railway*, Ltd., in the winter of 1905-6, and we had to consider the question of his successor. It had . been evident to ns that we were at a disad-vantage, as oompared to other land companies, in only having suoh time and attention as oould be devoted to our affairs by a staff who, however able and energetic, were busy railway officials, and attention to our inoreased basiness and the development and sales of our proporties reqaired that we should have a staff of our own. With the consent of the Delta Rvil ways, we appointed their ohief engineer as oor ma¬nager, and ha—Mr. J. W. Peacock —accordingly resigued the former appointment, and took up his duties as our manager in February last. Since that time the necessary staff of oar own has been got together, favourable purchases and sales have been effected, as I have already stated, and the active proseoation of oar basiness undertaken. It was not to be expected that much result could come into the period ended 31st March last, or,in other words, into the report and acoounts before you. As a matter of fact, no sales are entered, as none had been completed within the period. Per contra, our working expenses were only increased by the inclusion of a staff of our own for quite a short time, aud the small balance of profit may simply be regarded as the excess of rents and interest received over oar oharges for working. As more correotly indicating the benefits to ns of the ohangea made and the basiness done, I will state that, subject to their due completion, the result of sales effected between the 1st April And the 30th June is a profit to ns of at least £50,000, and we have reason to hope that sach sales will now proceed continuously. We regard it that oar position and prospeots woald be sufficient to jastifyasin recommending the payment even now of an interim dividend on aooount of the oarrent year, but purchases and sales of land in Egypt are usaally made by a system of de¬ferred payment, and there is an objection to anticipating the realisation of these instalments.

I prefer to a?k yon to exercise a little patienoe and look forward to the aooonnts of the oarrent year showing a substantial dividend,whioh they should do if 111 goes well. With referenoe to the proposal to increase this oompany’s oapital which was intended to be pot to you,it has been represented to us by oar legal advisers that as it was not our intention—as publicly stated by me—to make an issue before calling a meeting to consider the objects thereof, there is no ad¬vantage in taking powers to inorease our oapital now instead of at a later date, so as the prob¬ability of our now requiring more money is not clear this proposal will be farther postponed. The Board’s General Policy.

In conclusion, I offer you a few remarks upon our general polioy. We are a land and investment company, oar moneys raised consist of capital and of premia on shares. We may well expeot sach premia to equal or evea ex¬ceed our capita1. At present our moneys are nearly wholly invested in land purchases ; but we propose to confine these—in oonrse of time —praotioally to capital moneys, and from our premia to invest amounts at least equal to our oapital in sound mortgages, in boildings and sach things as supplies of light and water. On these latter we feel we oan get good returns for our money, and thoagh not so profitable aa dealings in land have been in the past, it safeguards ns against reaotion or cessation of profitable purchases. Before moving the adop¬tion of the directors’ report and accounts I shall be pleased to answer any questions which shareholders may wish to ask. (A pause). As no questions are asked, I now have to move the following resolution :—“That the report of ( the directors, dated 27th July, 1906, together with the audited statement of accounts and balance sheet for the half-year ended 31st March, 1906, be and they are hereby received, approved and adopted.” (Applause).
MsjorW. I. Le Breton seoonded the resolu¬tion, which was carried unanimously.
Major Le Breton next moved the re-election of Sir Auokland Colvin as a director.
Major-General H. J. Hallowes seconded the motion, which was unanimously agreed to.
The Chairman moved the re-election of. Baron J. de Menasce, of the Egyptian Board, as a director.
Major Le Breton seoonded the resolution, which was agreed to.
Mr. J. H. Basby moved the re election of Messrs. Meredith and Co. as auditors of the oompany for the ensuing year.
Mr. W. Baker seconded the motion, which was pat and oarried.
The Chairman: I now move that the following nine resolutions, which were passed at an extraordinary general meeting held 19th Jaly, 1906, be confirmed as speoial resolutions :—
That the memorandum and artioles of association be varied as follows :—

1. By striking out from seotion 3, sub¬section (a) of the memorandum of association the words "in any district,” and by snbstitnting for the words "in which the railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd., or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed or proposed to be con¬structed, may serve or be intended to serve,” oocarring in the same sab seotion the words "or in the Sadan.”
2. That Artiole 75 of the artioles of associa¬tion of the oompany be altered by striking oat the words oommenoing "aud every exercise of the power” down to the end of that artiole.
3. That article 81 be altered by striking out the words "or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.”
4. That Artiole 85 be altered by striking oat the words "provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any contract, dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.”
5. That Artiole 86 be altered by striking ont all words after the words "shall be vaoant.”
6. That Artiole 87 be altered by striking oat the words "save as aforesaid” appearing in the first line of such article.

7. That Artiole 89 be struck out, and that there bo substituted theTefor the following artiole : —"The remuneration of the directors shall be the sum of £250 per annum to eaoh of the direotors and £500 per annnm to the Chairman, and saoh re an aeration shall be deemed to aocrue de de in dien. The remune¬ration shall be exclusive of the sums, if any, which under the provisions of these presents the Beard may agree to pay to any managing director or t > any director on aceOaut of special services.”
8. That Artic'e 9 J be altered by striking o «t the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Ltd.”
9. That Artiole 96 be altered by strik'u? out the words "one director” and substituting therefor the words "two direotors.”
These resolutions we e daly seoonded by Major-General H. J. Hallow es and Mjor Le Breton respectively, and on being put severally to the meeting they were unanimon ly agreed to.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: There are reasons to believe that a deoree will shortly be published in which the Saltan will designate his son, Prince Mehemed Barhaneddin, as his successor to the throne. Prince Burhaneddine, born in 1885, is the fourth son ot Abdul Hamid, and aooording to the law, thirteen Princes have the right to the succession before him.
The wife of the late Prince Mohamed Bey Ibrahim is a well-known figure in the fashion¬able world of Paris, and she wa9 often in the company of the Daohess d’Uz.
Mr. Emmannel Benaohi, president of the Helleuio community at Alexandria, is at present in Athens, where he intends to stay for some time. He has purchased a splendid villa at Kephiesia.
Dixon Bey, direotor of the Ports and Lights Administration at Fort Said, is staying at San Moritz.

Mohamed Haddaya Bey, mamour of the Public Security Department at the Alexandria Goavernorat, arrived at Alexandria yesterday evening on his return from Europe via Port Said. He resumed his official duties this morning.

In oonsequenoe of the new regulations in-troduced into the Native Court ot Appeal, Cairo, Mohamed Bey Delawer will be appointed seoretary general to that Coart, after the retire¬ment of Ahmed Eff. Fahmi and Girgis Eff. Youssef, whose offices will be abolished at the beginning of next year.
Dr. Emin Ibrahim Fouleihan has been authorised to practise in Egypt

Voici cette solution, toujours d’après M. Dietrich :

Bile consiste tout simplement à créer à travers le lac Maréotfs entre les jardin» du Uxbbari et le Mariout an large chenal relié à la mer do chaque côté par do» pilotis servant à indiquer la direction de» bateaux. Ces améliorations olïictuée», le) quai» do Minet ôl Bissai auront un développement do 7600 métro), taudis que ceux prévus par l'in géniour eu obéi du port n'en auront que 6600 lo» berge» qui longent le canal maritime projeté par lui au sud do la voie ferré) étant inntilisa b le» à cause de» bas fond» orééU par le» rem biais du chemin de fer et lo» digues du oanal en que»tion. div.p: Au sujet du rapport de M. Dietrich Bey sur la construction d’un canal maritime, dont nous avons publié avant hior un aperçu, nous soin mes où ne peut plus surpris do trouver chez un de nos confrères locaux nue appréciation dia métralemeut opposée à la vérité. div.head: NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: A Londres, le Consolidé ang'ais est resté hier invarié à 87 5/8. L’IJnifiée a clôturé en hausse de 1/8 à 101 7/8. La National Bank est demeurée inchangée à 26, de meme «fie l’Agri- oole à ‘J 7/8 et la Daira à IG 7/8. La Delta Light a perdu 1/4 à 11 1/.'.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien et la Banque d’Athènes sont restées stationnaires à 755 et 145.
De même qu’hier, nous avons en, ce matin, un marché calme, avec tendance à la faiblesse sur quelques valeura et à la fermeté sur d'au¬tres titres.

La National Bank a clôturé plu» faible à 25 7/8 1,5/16. L’Agricole a conservé son prix pré-cédent, soit 9 11/16-3/4. La Cassa di ticonto a molli à 219 220 et la Banqno d’Athèoei à 146 147. Le Comptoir Financier s’est inscrit à G 5/8.
Le Crédit Folioter a baissé de 4 francs à 754 755. La Daira a également reculé à 16 11/16. La part de fondateur Immobilière s’est raffermie à 670.

L’action Entreprises Imm ibilières et Tra¬vaux a été recherchée à 4 1/4 5/16 ;la part de fondateur a été cotée 67-68. La part dé fonda-teur Agricole du Nil a fléchi à 7. L’action Allotmeut est revenue à 3 7/16.
Les Héliopolis ont débuté à 328 pour des-cendre à 310 ; la part de fondateur a été traitée aux abords de 8 1/2. Les Automobiles ont faibli à 5 1/4 5,16.
La part Bourse Khédiviale du Caire a été tégociée en hausse de 3 livres à 155-160.
Dans lo groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovith se sont maintenus à 17 5/16. Le» Egyptian ont é’é offerts à 6 1/4. L’Anglo- American Nile a été demandée à 5 7/16-1/2.
Parmi le» petites valeurr, les Delta Land ont c’ôturé à 3 7/16 vendeur». La part de fon¬dateur Estâtes a gagné 1/16 à It 11/16. Les Markets ont fait 24 sh. 9.

Le ministère des finances vient do trans-mettre aux membres du oonseil d’administra¬tion de la National Bank of Egypt une note confidentielle exposant les conditions aux-quelles le gouvernement khédivial sorait di» posé à approuver la transformation en Banque d’Etat de cet établissement dé crédit.

Ces conditions seraient jugées très avanta geuses et on ne doute pas «in'elles seront acceptées dans la prochaine réanion du conseil d'administration. Elles permettraient, entre antres, à la Banque de faire usage de son fonds de réserve, qui serait remplacé par les disponibilité» de l’Etat, dont une partie con-sidérable tout au moins serait mise, sans intérêt, à la disposition do la réserve de la Banque.

Les dorniors journaux anglais annoncent «pie la formation des deux Bocié'ét anonymes oi-après a été enregistrée à Londres le 3 Aoû‘ oourant: > 1 ' La Central Cboubrab Ltd , au capital de £ lOOOO'h représenté par 24 9c0 actions ordi-naires de £4 chacune ot 4,000 parts de fonda-teur à lbh. L’objet delà Compagnie est, en général, d'acquérir de» terrains et immeubles en Kgypto ou ailleurs, et, en particulier, pour un terrno de 60 ans, certains terrain» à Ghfz.’reh Badram (Cboubrab);d’adopter un arrangement avec la Société d’E .trepri-e» Immobilière» et Travaux et d’entreprendre des ali .iros de ter-rain», de construction, de commerce, etc. Lo premier conseil d’administiatiou e-it composé de MM. H. I. Sbaw, J. Ilirvey, C. J. Baker, F. W. Godwin, R. R. Bealo, G C. Rhodes, L P. Stephen et II. de Vries. 2U lia Centtal G reh Ltd.. au capital de £100,000, représenté par 24,?5 ) actions ordi-naires de £ 4 clucnno et 4,000 parts de fonda tour à 1 sh. L’objet de la Compagnie est, en général, d'acquérir des terrains ot immeuble» eu Egypte ou ailleurs, et, eu particulier, pour un terme de 60 ans. certains terrains dans Vile de Gbezireh, au Caire, d’adopter un arrange¬ment avec la So.-iété d’Eutreprise» lui mob i lières et de Travaux et d’entreprendre des affaires en terrain», constructions, etc. Les pre¬miers administrateurs sont les mômes que ceux de la Central Cboubrab. Ltd.

The Standard Life Assurance Company. K8TABLI8HKD ISiiO. 1 J Hoad Office | -3, GeorKO Street, Edinburgh.
THE ANTI-HELLENIC MOVEMENT.
THE PORTE SNUBBED.

SOFIA August 22. la reply to the Turkish Note, complaining of the anti Greek agitation in Bulgaria, the Government aaye that the Porte is not entitled to interfere in the internal affairs of the Prin¬cipality. The Greek peraeoutiona are merely the effect of anti-Bulgarian atrocitie8 in Mace¬donia. The Porte had better firat restore order in her own country. (fl««/ v)
SOFIA, August 22.
The Port > has addressed a Note to Bulgaria expreaaing its discontent in regard to the anti-Hellenic movement.
The Bulgarian Government has replied that it oonaidered the Note as nail and void, because the Porte has no right to meddle with the internal affairs of Bulgaria. (Ua/wu)
Constitution for China Conference to be Summoned
PEKING, August 22.

The Dowager-Empress is preparing plans for the summoning of a Conference of officials and | viceroys in order to discuss the adoption of a Constitution. The Commissioners who have retarned from th sir tour abroad reoommeud a Govaroinant180
Piracy in Cantonese Waters
THE "TIMES” WARNING.
LONDON, August 22.

The "Times” oomplains of the inorease of piiaoy in Cantonese waters and the growing indfferecce of the Chinese authorities to the rights of Europeans. It emphasizes the incapa¬city of the viceroy, and warns China that unless she suppresses the piracy Great Britain may undertake the work herself. (Reuter
CUBAN INSURRECTION REPULSE OF INSURGENTS.
New York, August 22.
Gomez, the famous leader who figured so prominently in the American War, has joined the rising io Cuba. Inhabitants in the country districts are flocking into Havana. {Reuter ’
Havana, August 22

610 arrests have been made here during the past three days, on the charge of conspiracy. ' Another fight took place Dear here yesterday. The insurgents were repulsed. Gomez has been arrested on his ranch. (R.)
THE DREADNOUGHT. A WORLD’S RECORD.
London, August 22.
It is announced from Portsmouth that the Dreadnought will be ready for sea by let September, three months before the stated time, thereby constituting a world’s record. (Reuter)
MEDITERRANEAN FLEET AT VENICE. A CORDIAL WELCOME.
Venice, August 22.

The Mediterranean ffoet has arrived here. It received a moat cordial welcome. The city v-as magnificently illuminated at night. The Venetians held a great serenade on the Piazza St. Mark and around.the warshipp. (Reuter)
FRENCH NAVAL ESTIMATES.
Paris, August 22.

A Parliamentary paper states that the estimated expenditure during 1907 on naval construction will amount to £4,270,560. The programme includes 10 battleships and 51 submarines. The to'peio boats are to he replaced by destroyers. (lltuter)
HOME CRICKET.
London, August 22
Cricket. —Gloucestershire beat Worcestershire by an innings ■and 230 rune. (Reuter)
London, August 22.

Middlesex beat Lancashire by 31 runs. York-^h'fe beat Surrey by 102 runs. Sussex beat Notts by 8 wickets. Essex beat Derbyshire 8 wicket’. The match between Leicestershire and Warwickshire was drawn. (R.t

div.head: THE CHILIAN EARTHQUAKE.
div.p: MORE TALES OF'DISASTER.
New York, August 22.
The latest careful estimate plabes the death-roll due to the Chlian earthquake at certainly soveral thousands. Each day brings news of towns and villages destroyed.
The authrr.ties at Santiago are building huts for 30,000 refugees and have ordered ships at Valparaiso to remove the houseless population.
Naval detachments are landing at Va’paraiso and assisting to maintain order and clear up the wreckage. The British Consulate has been destroyed and the Consol injured in the leg. (flatter)

div.head: EGYPT’S POSITION.
GERMAN INTERFERENCE.
ENGLISH PRESS OPINION-
div.p: The article in the "Deutsche Revue,” o which a summary appeared in our issue o Tuesday last, induce* the "Times” to make the following reflections :—

The attempt to construe political claims o any kind in Egypt upon the strength o commerrid and economic interests is ever morequestionab’e than in the case of Morocco Germany’s share represents only a small frao tiou of the to‘al trade of E/ypt and merely at infinitesimal fraction of the valne of her owe total exports and imports. The number o German tubjeots in Egypt amounts to juste little over 1 per cent, of the whole foreige population. Moreover, the value both of Ger man exports and imports t» and from Egypt considerably declined during 1905, asoompared with the year before. To nrge the extent of German interests in the Suez Canal in oon nexion with Egypt is not to the point, while to oarry out the threat which has ignorantly been made in one quarter and to revoke the German assent to the decree of 1901 with regard to the Publio Debt, would place Germany in a false position.

The motives from which th’s agitation has sprung are perhaps worth examination. The results of the Morocco campaign were hardly as satisfactory as Germany from her point of view could have desired. The further evidence ol harmony between the Mediterranean Powers which was exhibited by the Abyssinian Railway agreement has produced anything but a sooth ing effect in the ooui try. If English, French, and Italian should come to be established as the r ffirial languages in Egypt this arrangement wouli merely bn symbolical of a position in the Mediterranean to which G rmany can offer no parallel and lay no claim. The obief consideration, however, which appears to have weighed with the authors of the present agitation is the future of the Baghdad Railway. German writers are fond of protesting that the whole of the necessary capital has been found and that Germany is perfectly independent of foreign co-operation or foreign opposition. As Sir Edward Grey recently pointed out, that is a German sfftir. If Germany desiros assistance from outside the question of participation will no doubt be considered. Bat in spite of this vaunted self stfficienoy, it is evident that the d fficulties which have been encountered in connexion with the proposed increase in the Turkish Customs and the incontestable position of Great Britain in the Persian Gulf have aroused anxiety for the prospects of the railway. The manner in which the attitude of the British Ambassador at Constantinople with regard to the Cosh his questions has been criticized in the Press within a few hours of a co? fnenoe of the diplomat pj representativeaof the Kwjrabas a savour and moaning of its ojyu. The various difficulties, therefore, which surround the completion of the Baghdad Railway seem to have inspired the idea of imputing to Great Britain a deal re-to annex Egypt, simply for the purpose of propounding a one sided bargain. In order to compel acquiescence the threat of international investigation into Egyptian affairs is held out, with the further menace of growing dissatisfaction on the part of Franoe. The whole agitation seems to have lean designed as a trap, yet after Sir Edward Grey's plain statement with regard bot h to Egypt and t bi Baghdad Railway, the hope that the British Government might be iuduoed to walk into it must surely be abandoned.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: (Prom our Financial Correspondent).
London, August 17.
The Money Market.

Notwithstanding a downward tendenoy in foreign exchange the money market continues easy and even weak. For 6O-day bills soaroely 3 per cent, oan be got, which refleots the general opinion that for some time at any rate no rise in money is likely. The Bank position is excellent. Coin is already returning from the oountry, and with this and about half a million from abroad and a contraction of the note oiroulation of £426,COO, there is an addition to reserve of £1,147,000. This makes the proportion of oash to liabilities 50 per cent. The total reeerve is in fact the highest for ten years at this period of the year.
Silver,

The market for silver seems likely to rise. The United States have purchased 100,000 ' oz«., and India, contrary to expectation, is 1 coming in for considerable supplies. Egypt has j purchased a considerable amount recently. It is probable that with the present short supply in London and the prospect of a steady demand i of about 500,000 ozi.for America yearly which has now to be added to the usual demands I the price will go higher. The Egyptian Government may be congratulated upon buy-i ing at the right moment The price to-day is 30$d. but we should not be surprised to see it up Id. next week.
The Stock Markets,

I The nineteen day account just ended has failed to justify the evil reputation of its predecessors. Notwithstanding that the holiday season is at its height business has improved, and an inoreaee in values has been noted all round. Contrary to expectation the dissolution of the Duma by the Tsar has been taken lying down, and the feared general uprising has not come about, the result being an inclination to buy Russian securities. Gilt-edged Beourities have continued in favour during the past week and Consols have touohed 88$, but have now dropped back a little to f-8. Colonial loans are coming into favour and substantial advances have been noted. Johannesburg Fours have advauoed 3 points and Spanish and Turks have gained 1 to 2 points. Australian issues are in demand, con6is‘ent with the evidetce of the increased prosperity of the States of the Commonwealth.
Home Ralls.
The feature of the week has been Home
Rails.

The excellent half yearly returns, just published, have had a good effect and the publio are inolined to buy. Southern lines led the way, Brighton “ A ” showing a gain of 4$, being now quoted at 121$. Great Easterns were at one time 86$ bot have lost a little and are now at 84 j. North Easterns are favoured, being quoted at 141$, their traffic returns for last week being distinctly favourable, sbowiug an ioorease of £.0,000. Hull and Barnsleya are exceptionally strong with a sharp rise to 45$- The report of the "Distriot” is anything bat favourable, and a huge defioit for the half year has to be met, This unfavourable report does not seem to have had a g e it effa.’t on the market and oonfi fence s ems to be felt that Sir George Gibb will bring this liue ou a profit-earning basis.
Americans.

Yankee R always continue to receive support, and prices have advanoed generally. Uuion and Southern Pacifies are the feature on dividend prospects. Southern Pacifies are q opted at 84 $, and a dividend declared ou this stock tfioold have a beneficial effect on Unions, as the latter is the largest holder pf Southern Paoifio shares. Unions are now quoted 166$. Canadian*

Canadian Paoifios 6bow a recovery. A bonus has been anticipated, hat no statement has been made. It is felt that a defi iite official B?itement would be welcome. Grand Trunks continue in decided favour, the thirds receiving support at 69,
Egyptians.

Although prices do not close quite at the best, there is a good tone in Egyptians and some bufciness is being done. National Bat à of Egypt after being up to 26$ strong buyers close a good deal easier at 26. Agricultural Banks are also down from the best at 9 f $. There is absolutely no enquiry for Daira Sanieb, and the price is now only 16$ and the Deferred 96.

Delta Pref. (be *rer) have been bid for up to 11$, but close 11$. Delta Lind and Iuvest-1 jnent are buyers at 3$, bot no spllers about. 1 Kfiedivial Mail are once more in strong demand , from Egypt round about 34e. bot tbgre are I hardly any shares op this aide, so the price arp ! is very misleading, and if any were effered at' 35s. or even 36 , they wool 1 probably be taken . at once. Egyptian Estates have changed bands j in large quantities at 1 $$, but close sellers at this prioe. Daira Sugar remain unchanged | at 5$ and Union Fonciere at 6$. Bank of j Abyssinia are a quite nominal market 1$ 1 discoant. There is no change in Land Bank @ 8$, Corporation of Western Egypt at pm., and Salt and Soda –at. Egyptian Market j close at 11, and Bark of Ronmania at 10.
>Mining.

One of the greatest surprises of the account has been the interest displayed in Kaffirs. At this season of the year dealers are more inolined to take holidays than to think of opening fresh business. Paris has been a buyer and professional bidding has helped to maintain 'prices, and it is hoped that if sufficient interest oan be taken in this market until after the holidays the publio may be induced to oome in, and the oondition of things restored to their former level. The leading Kaffirs show gains, and any shares on offer are generally snapped up. Kand Mines have improved to 6 17/32, and after easing off a little have farther strengthened to 6 19/32. East Rands have hardened to 4 j, and Gold Fields have been in good demand at 4 13/32.

Egyptian mining shares have benefi'ed by the improved tone of other markets and a rise has been noted in some of the principal issues. United Africans Explorations oontinue in reqaest and have further hardened 3/32 to 1^ Nile Valleys have risen to 7s. and are a firm market. “Mommies,” after rising to 4/9, have had a slight relapse, and are now qaoted at 4/6. Iron and Stool.

The improvement in the iron and steel trade has at last made itself felt in the atook markets. Vickers have oontinned in strong demand and a farther rise to 51/9 has been the result. The Steel Company of Scotland have announced a dividend, 7| per cent, being recommended agaiust 5 per cant, for the previoos year and 2| per cent fn each of the three preceding years ?5,0( 0 is to be placad to the reserve, as compared with £5,003.

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.

Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
